qas.question: What was proposed for the abbey in June 2009?
On what date did the Dean and Chapter announce that work would not be continued?
Panter Hudspith refurbished a 14th-century foodstore into what?
What kind of furniture is in the restaurant?
Who supplied the furniture for the restaurant?
What was proposed for the abbey in June 2008?
On what date did the Dean and Chapter announce that work would be continued?
Panter Hudspith refurbished a 13th-century foodstore into what?
What kind of furniture isn't in the restaurant?
Who never supplied the furniture for the restaurant?

context: In June 2009 the first <a0_0><b5_0>major building work<b5_0/><a0_0/> at the abbey for 250 years was proposed. A corona—a crown-like architectural feature—was intended to be built around the lantern over the central crossing, replacing an existing pyramidal structure dating from the 1950s. This was part of a wider £23m development of the abbey expected to be completed in 2013. On <a1_0><b6_0>4 August 2010<b6_0/><a1_0/> the Dean and Chapter announced that, "[a]fter a considerable amount of preliminary and exploratory work", efforts toward the construction of a corona would not be continued. In 2012, architects Panter Hudspith completed refurbishment of the 14th-century food-store originally used by the abbey's monks, converting it into <a2_0><b7_0>a restaurant<b7_0/><a2_0/> with <a3_0><b8_0>English Oak<b8_0/><a3_0/> furniture by Covent Garden-based furniture makers <a4_0><b9_0>Luke Hughes and Company<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
